One can’t improve on Lucilius: “ Pull up chariot and horses as a good driver oft does.” And Carneades always compares the philosopher-’s suspension of judgment (ἐποχή) to the guard of a boxel· and the pulling up of a charioteer. But the inhibitio of rowers implies motion, and indeed the rather violent motion of rowing to back the boat. You see how much more attention I pay to this than either to rumour or to Pollio. Let me know too about Pansa, if anything definite is known, and I suppose it has come out, about Critonius, if there is any news, and anyhow about Metellus and Balbinus.

Come now, do you really think you ought toth-pinum, publish without my orders? Even Hermodorus June 30 or never did such a thing, though he used to circulate July 1, B.C. Plato's books, and that gave rise to the line “our 45 Hermodorus deals in dialogues.’'1 Do you really think you were justified in sending to anyone before you sent to Brutus, to whom at your advice I dedi- cated the work. For Balbus has written to me that you let him have a copy of the fifth book of the De Finibus, in which I have made a few alterations, though not many. However, I shall be obliged if you will keep back the others, so that Balbus may not get unrevised copies and Brutus what is stale.
